title: I saw this on a law firms website re: Bankruptcy. What is “junk-debt” discharge objection? They say its becoming more common.
question: Direct statement from law firms website, discussing Chapter 7 Bankruptcy
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy adversary proceeding,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Fees,Representing yourself
answers: If you are representing yourself and you do not have an attorney some creditors will file objection to discharge hoping you will not answer the lawsuit and the debt will be determined to be non-dischargeable. If the creditors want to object to your ability to obtain a discharge they can file an adversary proceeding, which is a lawsuit in the bankruptcy. You have to answer that (oppose it) if you don't they can win by default.

Yep....I'm 22 years in this business and never heard of that phrase, and do not see any such creditors objecting more often than others. In my client's cases we have objections in less than 1% of all cases from ANY creditor. If anything I see objections decreasing.

Add another vote for the statement making no sense. In fact, the term "junk debt" is a term that really has no real meaning. A debt is valid, or it is not. "Junk debt" is usually just used by lawyers and others in sales and marketing pitches.

Junk debt is debt bought by collection agencies for pennies on the dollar. I have not found that "junk debt" discharge objections are becoming more common. In fact, these debt buyers would seem to be less likely to object to discharge since they are so far removed from the circumstances around which the debts were incurred.

As a bankruptcy attorney since 1976, I have not encountered the term "junk debt" discharge objections. However, a creditor must exercise some caution before filing a complaint challenging the discharge of its debt because if they lose, they may have to pay the debtor's costs and attorney fees in defending the case. See 11 USC §523 for a list of the so-called "bankruptcy crimes". Good luck.

That is definitely an unusual term. I have been practicing bankruptcy for some time now, and have never heard that term. My best guess would be they are referring to an objection based on a claim of potentially fraudulent charges (recent purchases "on the eve" of bankruptcy). Those are the most common objections to discharge.
